format:

::: {.cell}

:::


# Lab 7 Recap

## Common Mistakes

2)  Question 8 (Interpret Confidence Interval): A lot of groups either did not include the population or they stated the population was the 13 marshes and not all marshes on the East coast. For this question, only one or two groups said the population was about crabs!

3)  Question 11 (Bootstrap Assumptions): A lot of groups did not talk about marshes and instead mentioned resampling. Some also mentioned that the population was crabs :(

# Statistical Critique 2

<!-- What they can / should work on to start -->

# 15-minute Work Session

# What did we do on Tuesday?

## 

::: {style="font-size: 2em; color: #000000;"}
We carried out a hypothesis test!
:::

::: columns
::: {.column width="35%"}
$$H_0: \beta_1 = 0$$

$$H_A: \beta_1 \neq 0$$
:::

::: {.column width="5%"}
:::

::: {.column width="60%"}

::: {.cell layout-align="center"}
::: {.cell-output-display}
![](week8-day2_files/figure-revealjs/evals-slr-1.png){fig-align='center' width=960}
:::
:::

:::
:::

::: {style="font-size: 1em; color: #ed8402;"}
What do these hypotheses mean *in words*?
:::

## 

::: {style="font-size: 2em; color: #000000;"}
By creating a permutation distribution!
:::


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
null_dist <- evals %>% 
  specify(response = score, 
          explanatory = bty_avg) %>% 
  hypothesise(null = "independence") %>% 
  generate(reps = 1000, type = "permute") %>% 
  calculate(stat = "slope")
```
:::


## 

::: {style="font-size: 2em; color: #000000;"}
And visualizing where our observed statistic fell on the distribution
:::

::: columns
::: {.column width="60%"}

::: {.cell}
::: {.cell-output-display}
![](week8-day2_files/figure-revealjs/unnamed-chunk-1-1.png){width=960}
:::
:::

:::

::: {.column width="5%"}
:::

::: {.column width="35%"}
::: {style="font-size: 1.5em; color: #34605f;"}
What would you estimate the p-value to be?
:::
:::
:::

## 

::: {style="font-size: 2em; color: #000000;"}
And calculated the p-value
:::


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
get_p_value(null_dist, 
            obs_stat = obs_slope, 
            direction = "two-sided")
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```
# A tibble: 1 Ã— 1
  p_value
    <dbl>
1       0
```


:::
:::


. . .

</br> 

What would you decide for this hypothesis test? What conclusion would you reach about these hypotheses?

## 

::: {style="font-size: 2.5em; color: #000000;"}
How would this process have changed if we used theory-based methods instead?
:::

## 

::: {style="font-size: 2em; color: #000000;"}
Approximating the permutation distribution
:::

::: columns
::: {.column width="40%"}
A $t$-distribution can be a reasonable approximation for the permutation distribution if certain conditions are not violated.
:::

::: {.column width="5%"}
:::

::: {.column width="55%"}

::: {.cell}
::: {.cell-output-display}
![](week8-day2_files/figure-revealjs/t-distribution-1.png){width=960}
:::
:::

:::
:::

## 

::: {style="font-size: 2em; color: #000000;"}
What about the observed statistic?
:::

::: panel-tabset
## Before


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
obs_slope <- evals %>% 
  specify(response = score, 
          explanatory = bty_avg) %>% 
  calculate(stat = "slope")
```
:::

::: {.cell}
::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```
   bty_avg 
0.06663704 
```


:::
:::


## Now


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
evals_lm <- lm(score ~ bty_avg,
               data = evals)

get_regression_table(evals_lm)
```
:::

::: {.cell}
::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```
# A tibble: 1 Ã— 1
  statistic
      <dbl>
1      4.09
```


:::
:::


:::

## 

::: {style="font-size: 2em; color: #000000;"}
How did R calculate the $t$-statistic?
:::

::: panel-tabset
## Step 1: SE

::: columns
::: {.column width="40%"}
$SE_{b_1} = \frac{\frac{s_y}{s_x} \cdot \sqrt{1 - r^2}}{\sqrt{n - 2}}$
:::

::: {.column width="5%"}
:::

::: {.column width="55%"}

::: {.cell}
::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```
[1] 0.01495204
```


:::
:::

:::
:::

## Step 2: t-statistic

::: columns
::: {.column width="40%"}
$t = \frac{b_1}{SE_{b_1}}$
:::

::: {.column width="5%"}
:::

::: {.column width="55%"}

::: {.cell}
::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```
bty_avg 
4.45672 
```


:::
:::

:::
:::

## Proof!


::: {.cell}
::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```
# A tibble: 1 Ã— 1
  statistic
      <dbl>
1      4.09
```


:::
:::

:::

## 

::: {style="font-size: 2em; color: #000000;"}
How does R calculate the p-value?
:::

. . .


::: {.cell layout-align="center"}
::: {.cell-output-display}
![](week8-day2_files/figure-revealjs/unnamed-chunk-10-1.png){fig-align='center' width=50%}
:::
:::


## 

::: {style="font-size: 3.5em; color: #34605f;"}
Did we get similar results between these methods?
:::

## 

::: {style="font-size: 2em; color: #000000;"}
Why not always use theoretical methods?
:::

. . .

::: columns
::: {.column width="45%"}
Theory-based methods only hold if the sampling distribution is normally shaped.
:::

::: {.column width="5%"}
:::

::: {.column width="45%"}
:::{.fragment}
The normality of a sampling distribution depends **heavily** on model conditions.
:::
:::
:::

## 

::: {style="font-size: 2em; color: #000000;"}
What are these "conditions"?
:::

. . .

::: columns
::: {.column width="40%"}
For linear regression we are assuming...
:::

::: {.column width="5%"}
:::

::: {.column width="55%"}
**L**inear relationship between $x$ and $y$

</br>

**I**ndepdent observations

</br>

**N**ormality of residuals

</br>

**E**qual variance of residuals
:::
:::

## 

::: {style="font-size: 2em; color: #000000;"}
**L**inear relationship between $x$ and $y$
:::


::: {.cell layout-align="center"}
::: {.cell-output-display}
![](week8-day2_files/figure-revealjs/unnamed-chunk-11-1.png){fig-align='center' width=960}
:::
:::


. . .

**What should we do?**

## 

::: {style="font-size: 2em; color: #000000;"}
Variable transformation!
:::


::: {.cell layout-align="center"}
::: {.cell-output-display}
![](week8-day2_files/figure-revealjs/transform-1.png){fig-align='center' width=960}
:::
:::


## 

::: {style="font-size: 2em; color: #000000;"}
**I**ndependence of observations
:::

::: columns
::: {.column width="40%"}
The `evals` dataset contains 463 observations on 94 professors. Meaning, professors have **multiple** observations.

</br>

*What can we do?*
:::

::: {.column width="5%"}
:::

::: {.column width="55%"}
:::{.fragment}
**Best** -- use a random effects model

**Reasonable** -- collapse the multiple scores into a single score
:::
:::
:::

## 

::: {style="font-size: 2em; color: #000000;"}
**N**ormality of residuals
:::


::: {.cell}
::: {.cell-output-display}
![](week8-day2_files/figure-revealjs/non-normal-1.png){width=960}
:::
:::


. . .

**What should we do?**

## 

::: {style="font-size: 2em; color: #000000;"}
Variable transformation!
:::


::: {.cell}
::: {.cell-output-display}
![](week8-day2_files/figure-revealjs/normal-1.png){width=960}
:::
:::


## 

::: {style="font-size: 2em; color: #000000;"}
**E**qual variance of residuals
:::


::: {.cell layout-align="center"}
::: {.cell-output-display}
![](week8-day2_files/figure-revealjs/non-constant-variance-1.png){fig-align='center' width=960}
:::
:::


. . .

**What should we do?**

## 

::: {style="font-size: 2em; color: #000000;"}
Variable transformation!
:::


::: {.cell}
::: {.cell-output-display}
![](week8-day2_files/figure-revealjs/unnamed-chunk-12-1.png){width=960}
:::
:::


## 

::: {style="font-size: 2em; color: #000000;"}
Are these conditions required for **both** methods?
:::

. . .

::: columns
::: {.column width="40%"}
::: {style="font-size: 1.5em; color: #34605f;"}
Simulation-based Methods
:::

::: {style="font-size: 0.75em; color: #000000;"}
-   Linearity of Relationship

-   Independence of Observations

-   Equal Variance of Residuals
:::
:::

::: {.column width="5%"}
:::

::: {.column width="45%"}
::: {style="font-size: 1.5em; color: #34605f;"}
Theory-based Methods
:::

::: {style="font-size: 0.75em; color: #000000;"}
-   Linearity of Relationship
-   Independence of Observations
:::

::: {style="font-size: 0.75em; color: #ed8402;"}
-   Normality of Residuals
:::

::: {style="font-size: 0.75em; color: #000000;"}
-   Equal Variance of Residuals
:::
:::
:::

## 

::: {style="font-size: 2em; color: #000000;"}
What happens if the conditions are violated?
:::

. . .

In general, when the conditions associated with these methods are violated, the permutation and $t$-distributions will [underestimate]{.underline} the true standard error of the sampling distribution.

. . .

- Our p-values will be **too** small!
- Our confidence intervals will be **too** narrow!
- We will make more Type I errors than we expect!

# Lab 8

<!-- Overview of what they are exploring -->

include-after-body:
<script>
  // htmlwidgets need to know to resize themselves when slides are shown/hidden.
  // Fire the "slideenter" event (handled by htmlwidgets.js) when the current
  // slide changes (different for each slide format).
  (function () {
    // dispatch for htmlwidgets
    function fireSlideEnter() {
      const event = window.document.createEvent("Event");
      event.initEvent("slideenter", true, true);
      window.document.dispatchEvent(event);
    }

    function fireSlideChanged(previousSlide, currentSlide) {
      fireSlideEnter();

      // dispatch for shiny
      if (window.jQuery) {
        if (previousSlide) {
          window.jQuery(previousSlide).trigger("hidden");
        }
        if (currentSlide) {
          window.jQuery(currentSlide).trigger("shown");
        }
      }
    }

    // hookup for slidy
    if (window.w3c_slidy) {
      window.w3c_slidy.add_observer(function (slide_num) {
        // slide_num starts at position 1
        fireSlideChanged(null, w3c_slidy.slides[slide_num - 1]);
      });
    }

  })();
</script>
